findings.title: CR - Code Repetition
findings.description: The contract contains repetitive code segments which can lead to issues like gas efficiency, complexity, readability, security, and maintainability of the source code.

findings.title: CCR - Contract Centralization Risk
findings.description: The contract's functionality and behavior are heavily dependent on external parameters or configurations, posing centralization risks such as Single Point of Control, Vulnerability to Attacks, Operational Delays, Trust Dependencies, and Decentralization Erosion.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. The `immutable` declaration can save gas by allowing certain optimizations.

findings.title: MVN - Misleading Variable Naming
findings.description: The contract uses some variable names that are too generic or do not clearly convey the information stored in the variable. The `_vaultOnly` variable's name suggests it is intended to restrict the execution of the `Swapout` function to only the vault address, but it is actually used as a toggle for the function's execution.

findings.title: MEM - Missing Error Messages
findings.description: The contract is missing error messages, making it difficult to identify and fix issues.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: TUU - Time Units Usage
findings.description: The contract is using arbitrary numbers to form time-related values, which decreases the readability of the codebase and prevents the compiler from optimizing the source code.

findings.title: VDB - Vault Delay Bypass
findings.description: The contract's `changeVault` function bypasses the delay mechanism implemented in the `setVault` and `applyVault` functions, undermining the intended security measure.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure their values cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not follow the Solidity naming conventions, which can lead to reduced readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be useful for optimizing code, but it can also be error-prone. It's important to carefully test and debug assembly code to ensure that it is correct and does not contain any errors.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
